newsitem.title: POLAND: Wroclaw shareholders protest merger term.
newsitem.headline: Wroclaw shareholders protest merger term.

text.p: A 5.2-percent shareholder of paintmaker Polifarb Wroclaw has sent a letter to the Polish Securities Commission protesting the terms of the firm's planned merger with Polifarb Cieszyn.

James Juracka of Credit Suisse Asset Management, which manages the London-listed Central European Growth Fund, said he wrote a letter for the fund and other U.S. and U.K. Wroclaw shareholders, asking the commission to prevent Cieszyn's version of the merger.

Cieszyn shareholders on Monday approved a version of the merger giving them 53.5 rather than 50 percent of the new firm by increasing a planned pre-merger bonus issue for Cieszyn shareholders to 6.375 from 2.98 million shares.

"We want the merger to take place...that's not the issue, the issue is preventing a six-million-share bonus issue of Cieszyn until there could be an informed discussion between the two firms' shareholders," Juracka said.

In December last year the two firms agreed on a one-for-one merger but Pioneer First Polish Trust Fund Co, which has a bigger share in Cieszyn than Wroclaw, proposed the greater bonus issue a few days before Cieszyn's meeting on Monday.
Wroclaw currently has 22,103,820 shares, 2,978,820 more than Cieszyn.

Juracka said the new proposal came late enough after the original December plan to prevent Wroclaw shareholders opposing Cieszyn's version to set up a proper voting bloc at the Tuesday Wroclaw meeting.
He said then only 100,000 other shares joined his fund with over a million shares against the merger plan's late changes.
"I think most Wroclaw shareholders are now realising that what actually happened is not what they thought was going to happen....(that) they would get 50-50 in the merged concern," Juracka said.
Wroclaw officials have said a mutual shareholder, BIG, might dispute Cieszyn's action in court but that the merger was still likely to go through as a delay would cost both firms.

Pioneer spokesman Miroslaw Lubon told Reuters on Thursday that it was hard to speculate on a letter which his firm had not seen but that Pioneer kept its view that Cieszyn was higher valued due to a higher mid-term earnings potential.
"It seems that everything shows that the proportion (of the merger) should be as we proposed it," Lubon said.
No one at the securities commission was immediately available for comment.

Juracka said there were arguments for each firm to receive a greater amount of the new firm, such as Wroclaw's higher margins and Cieszyn's higher investment, but that each side's arguments tended to cancel the other's out.
